newsitem.title: UK: HORSE RACING-DUNWOODY LANDS RECORD FOURTH KING GEORGE WIN.
newsitem.headline: HORSE RACING-DUNWOODY LANDS RECORD FOURTH KING GEORGE WIN.

text.p: Richard Dunwoody became the first jockey to win the King George VI Chase four times when triumphing on hot favourite One Man at Kempton on Thursday.
Dunwoody, who won the race on One Man last year and twice previously on the great Desert Orchid, never had an anxious moment.
Only five ran because of the ground hardened by overnight frost but they included the Grand National winner Rough Quest.
Trainer Terry Casey left it until an hour before the race before finally deciding to run Rough Quest, who prefers ground with some give.
One Man, the 8-13 favourite, took over from the pace-making Mr Mulligan turning into the straight and won the three mile (4.8 km) event easily.
Mr Mulligan, ridden by champion jockey Tony McCoy, fell at the last obstacle, allowing Rough Quest to finish second at 4-1 ahead of 10-1 outsider Barton Bank, winner of this race three years ago.
Dunwoody, who had 12 lengths to spare at the post, said: "He gave me a great ride and he jumped superbly."
Owner John Hales, who could only bring himself to watch his grey horse after the final fence, said: "We came into the racing knowing nothing and we"ve finished up with One Man."
Trainer Gordon Richards has now won the prestigious King George three times, twice with One Man and once with Titus Oates back in 1969.
One Man will be aimed again at the Cheltenham Gold Cup in which he finished a disappointing sixth last season in a rare failure.
